data.title: Answers to: What are the evidences of early civilizations in Myanmar
data.meta_description:
Some of the evidences of early civilizations in Myanmar include:

1. Pyu Ancient Cities: The Pyu cit...
data.text:
Some of the evidences of early civilizations in Myanmar include: 1. Pyu Ancient Cities: The Pyu city-states, located in present-day Myanmar, date back to the 1st century CE. Archaeological excavations have revealed the remains of walled cities, moats, palaces, and Buddhist stupas, indicating a well-organized civilization. 2. Beikthano-Central Myanmar: Beikthano is an archaeological site in central Myanmar that flourished between the 4th and 9th centuries CE. Excavations here have uncovered multiple brick structures, religious sites, and artifacts, suggesting a complex urban center. 3. Mon Kingdoms: The Mon people, inhabiting present-day Lower Myanmar, had sophisticated civilizations during the 1st to 11th centuries CE. The excavation of ancient temples, monasteries, statues, and inscriptions in Mon script is evidence of their cultural and architectural advancements. 4. Bagan Empire: Bagan (9th to 13th centuries CE) was a powerful kingdom in Myanmar. Thousands of Buddhist temples, pagodas, and monasteries were built during this time. Bagan's archaeological sites provide evidence of an influential civilization with advanced architecture. 5. Mrauk U Kingdom: Mrauk U, located in present-day Rakhine State, flourished between the 15th and 18th centuries CE. The ruins of the royal palace, temples, and fortifications showcase the grandeur of this powerful kingdom. 6. Stone Age Cave Art: In the Padah-Lin Caves of Shan State, rock art dating back 10,000 years has been discovered. These paintings depict scenes of hunting, dancing, and rituals, offering insights into the lifestyle and practices of early inhabitants. 7. Bronze Age Sites: The discovery of bronze artifacts and burial sites in sites like Ban Chiang in northern Thailand, near the Myanmar border, and Mae Moh in western Thailand, suggest connections with early civilizations and trading networks in Myanmar. These archaeological discoveries provide compelling evidence of early civilizations in Myanmar and their cultural, artistic, and architectural achievements.

There are several evidences of early civilizations in Myanmar, including: 1. Pyu Ancient Cities: Pyu Ancient Cities were established around the 2nd century BCE and flourished until the 9th century CE. The cities of Halin, Beikthano, and Sri Ksetra have been identified as key Pyu sites, exhibiting the urban planning and architectural features of early civilization. 2. Mon Kingdoms: The Mon civilization emerged in the 6th century BCE and established several influential kingdoms, including Thaton and Bago. Evidence of their civilization can be found in the ancient structures, such as temples, stupas, and city walls, that still exist today. 3. Bagan Archaeological Zone: Bagan was the capital of the Pagan Kingdom and thrived from the 9th to 13th century CE. It is known for its vast collection of over 2,000 pagodas and temples, which provide evidence of the advanced artistic and architectural skills of the civilization. 4. Mrauk U: Located in present-day Rakhine State, Mrauk U was the capital of the Arakan Kingdom from the 15th to 18th century CE. It was a major trading hub and boasted impressive temples, fortresses, and historical artifacts, indicating the existence of an advanced civilization. 5. Pyay and Tagaung: Pyay, also known as Prome, was an ancient Burmese capital and archaeological evidence suggests the existence of urban civilization in this region as early as the 2nd century BCE. Tagaung, another early capital, is believed to have been founded in the 7th century BCE, with archaeological findings supporting this claim. These archaeological sites, historic artifacts, and remnants of ancient structures provide tangible evidence of early civilizations in Myanmar, contributing to our understanding of the country's rich cultural and historical heritage.
